JEFF MASON, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, "REUTERS": Yes, in many ways I think he did today what he was trying to do Wednesday and was unsuccessful at Wednesday, in saying that we are on top of this. We are taking action to fix maybe some of the things that didn't go super well at the beginning with regard to testing. And even saying that he is prepared to help the airline industry and the cruise ship industry if it comes to that. So definitely saying things that the market wanted to hear and has not heard before today.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Maybe beyond the market, Byron, there was this confidence urge, a want for a feeling of confidence that the nation was together in fighting this. BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": Yes. I think that Trump had lost control of the public discussion of this, and I think today he got it back. Before today, I think he was responsible for the single best action in all of this, which was the China travel restrictions, and the single worst action, which was losing control or falling behind on the whole testing issue, not taking that seriously enough and making it happen. And then after the primetime address on Wednesday night just did not work. There were errors in it. He looked nervous. The Dow just crashed the next day. And I think this was an entirely different event, as Jeff was saying. It was a really, really different feel to the event.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Meantime, he was asked about this coronavirus bill up on Capitol Hill. Here's how he responded and how one congressman was worried about it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We just don't think they are giving enough. We don't think the Democrats are giving enough. We are negotiating. We thought we had something, but all of a sudden, they didn't agree to certain things that they agreed to. So we could have something but we don't think they are giving enough. They are not doing what's right for the country.

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDY BIGGS (R-AZ)
utterances.utterance: This has got a little, some other social engineering stuff in it as well. So they put in $1 billion that wasn't subject to the Hyde Amendment, which means that you could spend up to $1 billion effectively on state sponsored abortions, state funded abortions. So, it's hard to say, yet, what it's going to be.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Speaker Pelosi saying she has a deal. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says there is a deal. What we don't know is what is in the deal. And I don't think there is a lot of lawmakers up there on Capitol Hill who know what's in the deal.

utterances.speaker: STEVE HAYES, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Correct. I think lawmakers are clueless trying to find out what's in the deal. And I don't think President Trump has yet agreed to the deal. I think we would see a tweet from President Trump if he had already agreed to the deal. We'll learn more about what's happening. I agree with you that the event at the White House was a positive step. I think at least does one thing. It ends the debate over whether this is a serious problem or not, which for the past four weeks we have been having. And the president led a chorus, I think, of irresponsible commentary suggesting that this wasn't something that needed to be taken seriously, including a lot of talking heads. I hope that that is now settled. What we need now are facts. We need the president to lead on facts and to not provide bad information. I think it would be better off if the president stepped back and let Mike Pence and let the medical professionals do the talking for him.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: He did do that a number of times, bringing Tony Fauci up to the microphone who has become this really authoritative and plainspoken in cutting through, not sugar-coating it.

utterances.speaker: MASON
utterances.utterance: For sure, and in fact not sugar-coating it to the effect, or to the point that he said this week that it had been a failure, what had happened with the tests. And you didn't hear President Trump admonishing him for that. You didn't hear President Trump, expressing his --

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: And the question is whether this effort, and it seemed like they rolled it out really well, about these companies, if they are going to get these tests going quickly.

utterances.speaker: YORK
utterances.utterance: Well, that's what they say. The CEO effort was good. The other thing that's been good in the last 48 hours or so is state and local governments are gearing up. For several days Andrew Cuomo, the governor of New York, was complaining that we here in New York are ready to start some testing. We can get some things done. The federal government won't let us. Now they can.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: The floodgates are open. I wish we had more time for Winners and Losers. Panel, thanks. When we come back, "Notable Quotables."

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: It's been a long week. But it's Friday. That means "Notable Quotables."

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: My fellow Americans.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY)
utterances.utterance: Our hospitals, doctors, researchers, and public health officials are flying blind.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We would recommend that there not be large crowds. If that means not having any people in the audience when the NBA plays, so be it.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: Civilization as we know it is at stake.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The likelihood of a recession globally right now is certainly above 50.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY)
utterances.utterance: When you have a Democratic House and a Republican Senate, compromise is the name of the game.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I'll be working with companies, small companies, large companies, a lot of companies.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: No one is more worried about Dow Jones than the Jones family.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Bottom line, it's going to get worse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Let's shut the puppy down and let's move on and worry about November. This thing is decided. There is no reason to keep it going not even a day longer.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (D-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: We have got a whole lot of delegates to go.

utterances.speaker: PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: I really thought we had a shot. But turns out I was about 40 years too young and 38 years to gay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Your face lit up when I mentioned your grandkids. How old is the oldest grandkid, like, 60, 63?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Go wash her hands.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: OK, I like that.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: A little chicken wing there at the press conference. This weekend on "Fox News Sunday," Chris Wallace will speak with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin. We'll find out details about what that deal is all about, if there is a deal. Check your local listings for air times. Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid. Try to make it a great weekend, sports or no sports. Content and Programming Copyright 2020 Fox News Network, LLC.
